Award.AwardTitle: Improving the Undergraduate Learning and Teaching Experience Through Innovative Course Clustering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The biology and chemistry faculty of New Jersey City University will institute a new laboratory curriculum exploring the concept of "course clusters". These are logical, cross-disciplinary groupings of advanced undergraduate courses that span both biology and chemistry. Students within a cluster will work collaboratively to pursue a single common project using their respective laboratory components, regardless of which course they are enrolled in. This will model a cross-functional, authentic research experience involving multiple disciplines to solve a real-world problem, as is done in an industrial setting. Students will interact with each other in a collaborative environment and develop the skills needed for the STEM workforce. Due to the diverse nature of students at New Jersey City University, the project will increase the number and diversity of students pursuing STEM.

This project will develop a unique methodology to improve and broaden the scope of the biology and chemistry laboratory curriculum. The course clusters will form an integrated approach to addressing real-world research topics in an undergraduate setting. This approach mirrors the paradigm utilized by research-driven organizations to solve problems, so students will develop both the technical skills and the soft skills required to be workforce-ready upon graduation. Working with a project evaluator, the investigators will generate new evidence regarding how course-clustering increases student understanding of fundamental scientific principles, and how it influences non-cognitive student outcomes. The expected outcomes include improved self-efficacy, retention and graduation rates, satisfaction with the curriculum for both students and faculty, and placement in industrial positions and graduate schools. Program success will be assessed using validated survey tools and compared to historical data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A well-trained, diverse STEM workforce is crucial to the economic competitiveness of the United States. One of the goals of the STEM departments at New Jersey City University has been to prepare students who are under-represented in the STEM fields to participate in the science of tomorrow by providing them the skillset needed for success. The modern research environment is multidisciplinary and cross functional, requiring individuals to be expert in their own fields while working in collaboration with scientists from other disciplines to solve complex problems. The New Jersey City University Biology and Chemistry departments developed a new laboratory curriculum that reflects the technical and soft skills that are required to function effectively in research-intensive organizations by utilizing a course cluster consisting of courses from both departments that essentially mimics the research arm of a corporation such as a pharmaceutical company. Students undertook an authentic, research-based lab project developed in-house focused on identifying antibacterial compounds, a topic of current interest due the emergence of drug-resistant bacteria. Students in the organic chemistry class prepared molecules that could potentially exhibit antibacterial activity. These molecules were tested by the microbiology class to determine if they did indeed have the desired activity. The biological data was then given back to the organic class to use in the design of new molecules which would be prepared and presented to the microbiology class for testing. This iterative method mirrors the process in a drug discovery company and exposed the students to new scientific methods, new concepts like the study of structure-activity relationships (SAR) as well as the soft skill of cross-functional teamwork and collaboration. 

This project also contributed to the training of multiple undergraduate and high school students as part of our undergraduate research program. Student researchers developed new experimental methods and chemical procedures in both organic chemistry and microbiology for use in the teaching labs. Their efforts resulted in multiple student- and faculty-authored presentations and publications. Overall, the faculty and student reaction to the project was positive, and it has become a permanent addition to our curriculum.
